awd_titl_txt: The Origin of Voluminous, Hydrous, High-SiO2 Rhyolites at Long Valley, CA: High-resolution Numerical Thermal Models and Dynamic, Hydrous Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
High-silica rhyolite is the most differentiated silicate magma type on Earth and makes up some of the largest explosive eruptions (100's-1000's cubic km), including those at Yellowstone (WY) and Long Valley (CA) calderas in the last 1 Myr.  Understanding the origin and transport of high-SiO2 rhyolites and what triggers their eruption in large volumes, often explosively, is of considerable interest because their formation must fundamentally re-constitute and differentiate continental crust Additionally, the western U.S. may be the site of future "supervolcano" eruptions, and so understanding the process of the eruptive process can yield additional insight into the hazard associated with these eruptions.  Although the chances of a major catastrophic eruption in the western U.S. in the immediate future are low, one of the primary goals of this proposal is to test whether the timescales between rhyolite melt formation and rapid transport to the surface (via dikes) may be on the order of weeks and months (and thus human time scales) and not 10's to 100's of thousands of years.

The overall purpose of this study is to combine dynamic, hydrous partial melting experiments with 1D and 2D high-resolution numerical models to examine how the influx of volatile-bearing basalt into continental crust drives the formation, segregation and eruption of high-SiO2 rhyolitic melts. The high-resolution, numerical models will focus on processes that occur over short spatial (meter) and temporal (days/years) scales, in addition to those that operate over crustal distances (kms) and longer times (Myrs).  There are four important phenomena that are captured by high-resolution models, including: (1) The transfer of exsolved H2O-rich fluid from crystallizing basaltic sills (10-100 m) to adjacent wall rock, (2) The transient (100's of years) heating of the wall rock adjacent to newly emplaced basaltic sills, which leads to significant partial melting of surrounding crust (both granitoid and previously solidified mafic sills) under H2O-present conditions (where fluid-saturated conditions prevail at the solidus, but fluid-absent conditions develop at melt fractions over 20%). (3) The interaction of partial melts of granitoid and previously solidified mafic sills. (4) The role of pre-existing aplite dikes in granitoid wall rock in facilitating the rapid development of melt-filled dikes, and thus rapid transport out of the wall-rock source region.  These short-term processes impact crustal-scale thermal profiles because of the rapid transfer of heat via advection (i.e., dikes). They also lead to significant and irreversible compositional re-working of the upper crust due to the transport of these partial melts from both granitoid and previously solidified mafic sills; thus the re-worked upper crust will carry the geochemical signature of this mixed heritage. Dynamic, hydrous experiments will be performed that simulate the release of H2O fluid from the basaltic sills into adjacent wall rock, and its role in driving partial melting.  The new numerical models and software codes will be made widely available to facilitate scientific reproducibility and comprehension. Throughout the course of this work, several undergraduate and graduate students will be supported.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:  High-silica rhyolite (≥ 76 wt% SiO2) is the most differentiated silicate magma type on Earth and makes up some of the largest explosive eruptions (>100-1000 km3), including those at Yellowstone (WY) and Long Valley (CA) calderas in the last 1 Myr. Understanding the origin of high-SiO2 rhyolites and what triggers their eruption in large volumes, often explosively, is of considerable interest because their formation must fundamentally re-constitute and differentiate continental crust, and the western U.S. may be the site of future supervolcano eruptions.  During this grant period, geochemical and thermodynamic constraints were combined with geophysical and numerical modeling to understand the origin of the voluminous high-SiO2 rhyolites that erupted from the Long Valley volcanic field in eastern CA, including the 765 ka caldera-forming Bishop Tuff (>600 km3) as well as the 2.1-0.8 Ma precursor Glass Mountain units (100 km3).

Intellectual Merit: One of the key outcomes of this project was the successful development of a new, high-resolution numerical model (TIRAMISU), which was used to track the thermal and compositional evolution of the granitoid crustal column beneath Long Valley due to the influx of basalt. The new TIRAMISU model will be made fully available on the GitHub repository so that other researchers have access to the evolving code and can potentially contribute to its development.  Another outcome was the determination of temperatures and water contents in coeval Long Valley basalts (representative of the mantle-derived melts that drove rhyolite melt generation through their emplacement in the crust), which were incorporated into the TIRAMISU model along with additional geochemical constraints (e.g., isotopic compositions of pre-exising crust, mantle-derived basalt and erupted rhyolite).

A key finding from the application of our high-resolution TIRAMISU model, when applied to the crustal column beneath the Long Valley volcanic field, is that processes that occur over short time scales (<100 yrs) and short length scales (<100 m) have crustal-scale impacts.  For example, important phenomena captured by our new model include: (1) the efficient transfer of exsolved H2O-rich fluid from crystallizing basaltic intrusions (with high aspect ratios; ~50 m thick) to adjacent granitoid wall rock over ≤100 m length scales, (2) the transient (≤100s of years) heating and partial melting of the granitoid wall rock adjacent to newly emplaced basaltic sills, leading to significant partial melting of wall rock under hydrous conditions, and (3) the role of pre-existing thin dikes (~5-20 cm wide; made of high-SiO2 rhyolite) in granitoid wall rock in facilitating the rapid development of melt-filled dikes, and efficient segregation of interstitial rhyolite melt out of the wall-rock granitoid and basaltic sills. It is further shown that the transport of rhyolite melts within the crustal column is enabled by the gradual expansion (lengthening and widening) of a rhyolite dike network. These short-term processes impact crustal-scale thermal and compositional profiles due to the dike transport of the rhyolite melts. 

Another key finding is that a three-stage process of basalt emplacement into the crustal column (i.e., basalts emplaced into the lower, middle and upper crust, respectively), spanning 1-2 Myr duration, leads to the formation of voluminous rhyolite melts with geochemical characteristics (e.g., Sr and Nd isotopic signatures) that broadly match those erupted from the Long Valley volcanic field.  It is proposed that some of the erupted rhyolites were held in cold storage (fully crystallized) in a dike swarm, where individual dikes were wide enough (> 5m) so that upon re-melting they could immediately ascend and erupt without freezing.  The timescale for rapid mobilization of such a dike swarm is on the order of weeks and months, and thus on human time scales. 

Broader Impacts: This project contributed to the training of four PhD students (one from an under-represented background). All four students benefited from the interdisciplinary nature (geochemistry/thermodynamics with geophysics/numerical modeling) of the work. The PhD student that was primarily involved with code development of TIRAMISU is now a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Bayreuth, Germany; she attained the position on the basis of the skills she acquired during this project.  Another Ph.D. student is now an assistant professor at St. Lawrence University, New York.  The third Ph.D. student is now working in higher education as a student advisor for minority groups in the STEM fields.  The fourth Ph.D. student is currently working in the environmental consulting field.  In addition, an undergraduate field trip to the Long Valley volcanic field was run for University of Michigan students in the summer of 2019, and included those recruited from diverse, underrepresented backgrounds.
